title.narrative: 2 MATERNAL, NEWBORN INTERVENTION

description.narrative: Increased national capacity to provide access to essential high-impact maternal and newborn health interventions, which contributes to Maternal And Newborn Health. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2017, strengthened health systems, ensure that children and women have equitable access to and use, improved and quality, high- impact maternal, neonatal and child health interventions and adopt healthy

sector.narrative: Community and home based maternal and newborn care
Facility based maternal and newborn care (including emergency obstetric and newborn care, quality improvement)
Maternal and newborn care policy advocacy, evidence generation, national / subnational capacity development

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Increased national capacity to provide access to essential high-impact maternal and newborn health interventions

description.narrative: 100% of health facilities in supported states experiencing no stock-outs of key tracer maternal and newborn health commodities in the last one month (May 2017). This was possible through support from EU and Global Affairs Canada (GAC) that provided funding for procurement of health supplies amounting to about $12 million | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2017

title.narrative: Number of Health workers with capacity to provide quality MNCH services

actual.value: 2015:1,262 HCWs trained on various MNCH thematic areas along the continuum of care including 33 HCWs on HCT in Adamawa and 23 Nurses on ICCM in Delta State.Supported the conduct of bi-monthly CTC and LGA quarterly ISS visits to HFs in Kaduna, Ogun, Lagos, Akwa Ibom, Cross River, Benue, Imo, Ebonyi Sokot

title.narrative: Number of States with at least 60% of mothers and newborns in targeted areas receiving postnatal care within two days of childbirth (Number of mothers reached with UNICEF support will also be reported)

actual.value: 2015:Number of States increased from 7 states in 2014 to 9 states (25%) in 2015 namely Rivers, Gombe, Ogun, Abia, Jigawa, kaduna, Lagos, Niger, and Yobe.. However, PNC/homevisits were conducted in 21 States. Nationally, 136,413 postnatal care visits within 3 days of delivery have been reported. The Integ

title.narrative: Number of LGAs implementing policy for PNC/home visits to newborns within 72 hrs

actual.value: 2015:PNC/home visits is taking place in 155 LGAs in Nigeria. Majority of the PNC visits are being supported in 126 LGAs in 6 states. 2,480 CORPs and 350 VCMs from 24 LGAs in Adamawa and Kebbi State have their capacity built to conduct outreaches and home visitsContinued support provided to CHEWs to pro

title.narrative: Proportion of health facilities supported experiencing no stock-outs of key tracer maternal and newborn health commodities in the last one month

actual.value: 2015:Nationally, 91.5% of HFs did not experience stock-out of the 13 Life Saving Commodities in 2015. UNICEF, with support from the EU, BMGF, DFATD, GOJ, contributed to this success story. title.narrative: Percentage of UNICEF supported health facilities offering delivery services with functional newborn resuscitation equipment (functional bag and mask in neonatal size)
